channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: For Covid-19 Vaccines, Some Are Too Rich — and Too Poor
item.description: Global inequality is shaping which countries get vaccines first. In South Africa, people’s best chance for vaccines anytime soon is to join an experimental trial.
item.dc:creator: Matt Apuzzo and Selam Gebrekidan
item.media:credit: Joao Silva/The New York Times
item.media:description: Participating in a Johnson & Johnson vaccine trial this month at the Desmond Tutu H.I.V. Foundation Youth Center near Cape Town.

item.title: Refugees Come Under Fire as Old Foes Fight in Concert in Ethiopia
item.description: Forces from neighboring Eritrea have joined the war in northern Ethiopia, and have rampaged through refugee camps committing human rights violations, officials and witnesses say.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh and Simon Marks
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Eduardo Soteras/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: At the border, in Humera, between Ethiopia and Eritrea. Two countries that once fought a bitter war now appear to be allied in a fight to subdue the Tigray region of Ethiopia.

item.title: Chinese Citizen Journalist Sentenced to 4 Years for Covid Reporting
item.description: Zhang Zhan, a former lawyer, is the first known person to be tried for challenging the Chinese government’s narrative about the coronavirus pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Leo Ramirez/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Shanghai Pudong New District People’s Court, where the citizen journalist Zhang Zhan was sentenced after reporting on the early days of the pandemic.

item.title: Loujain al-Halthloul, Saudi Rights Activist, Gets Prison Sentence
item.description: Loujain al-Hathloul, who was arrested just before the driving ban was lifted, was charged with undermining the kingdom in a case that supporters decried as a political persecution.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Loujain Al-Hathloul, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Loujain al-Hathloul, a prominent figure in the push to allow women to drive, filmed herself at the wheel in 2014.

item.title: Pope Francis Strips Powerful Vatican Office of Its Financial Assets
item.description: A financial scandal involving the secretariat of state has given fresh impetus to Francis’ reform agenda.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Gregorio Borgia/Associated Press
item.media:description: The pope ordered the secretariat of state to transfer all of its financial holdings and real estate assets to another office.

item.title: Austrian Lockdown Covers Schools and Stores, but Not Ski Hills
item.description: A sunny holiday weekend drew a crush of skiers to Austria’s slopes, with crowded lift lines and parking lots making a mockery of social distancing rules.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Lisi Niesner/Reuters
item.media:description: Austria’s ski season, which began the day before Christmas, has led to traffic jams and long, crowded lift lines.

item.title: Italy Turns to Flower Power to Help Spread Vaccine Message
item.description: The architect Stefano Boeri has designed primrose-themed pavilions where coronavirus shots will be given, but not everybody is thrilled with the idea.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Stefano Boeri Architetti/via Reuters
item.media:description: A computer-generated image showing a pavilion designed by the architect Stefano Boeri.

item.title: E.U.’s Mass Vaccination Campaign Starts, With Nursing Homes as Focus
item.description: An ambitious plan to inoculate more than 450 million people comes at a precarious moment for the continent, with many countries struggling with their worst outbreaks since the start of the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy and Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: A resident of a nursing home in Munich received an injection of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine on Sunday.

item.title: In a Village of Widows, the Opium Trade Has Taken a Deadly Toll
item.description: Afghan men in an impoverished border settlement die trying to smuggle opium into Iran, leaving behind loved ones forced to survive on their own.
item.dc:creator: David Zucchino and Najim Rahim
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Women in Qala-e-Biwaha, or the “village of widows.” They survive on earnings from the wool-processing trade, or donations from relatives and aid groups.

item.title: Battered Turkish Economy Puts a Powerful Erdogan to the Test
item.description: Turkey’s veteran leader played an aggressive hand abroad, but as the country’s economy plummets, he is feeling ire at home as many Turks struggle to buy food.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Sedat Suna/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A ferry passing through Istanbul. Nine months into the pandemic, there are signs that a significant portion of the population is overwhelmed by debt and increasingly going hungry.

item.title: Ex-Military Officers Criticize Spain’s Government and Praise Franco
item.description: The comments by former officers, and some current ones, struck a raw nerve in a country that had been ruled by a military dictatorship.
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder
item.media:credit: Carlos Alvarez/Getty Images
item.media:description: The National Day military parade in Madrid in October.

item.title: As Virus Resurges in Africa, Doctors Fear the Worst Is Yet to Come
item.description: The coronavirus killed far fewer people in Africa than in Europe and the Americas, leading to a widespread perception that it was a disease of the West. Now, a tide of new cases on the continent is raising alarms.
item.dc:creator: Sheri Fink
item.media:credit: Samantha Reinders for The New York Times

item.title: Brazil Is Famous for Its Meat. But Vegetarianism Is Soaring.
item.description: The number of vegetarians in Brazil doubled over a six-year period, which has given rise to a booming plant-based industry that is seeking to turn meatpacking plants obsolete.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Participants gather for a mindful eating class in Rio de Janeiro. The number of vegetarians in Brazil nearly doubled between 2012 and 2018.

item.title: Welcoming a New Year at an Ancient Festival in Pakistan
item.description: Chawmos, a festival of Pakistan’s tiny Kalash community, is a portrait in contrasts: solemn ritual and joyous dancing, gender segregation and public flirtation, togetherness and isolation.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Conway
item.media:credit: Rebecca Conway for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the Kalash tribe dance and sing during celebrations to mark the Chaumous festival in Balanguru village, in the Rumbur Valley in northern Pakistan, in December.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: A terrorism suspect, disguised as a refugee.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Franco A. in his ‘‘prepper’’ basement in Offenbach, Germany.

item.title: A Far-Right Terrorism Suspect With a Refugee Disguise: The Tale of Franco A.
item.description: A German officer is facing trial on terrorism charges. At a volatile time for Western democracy, his story mirrors the story of Germany itself.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Franco A. in his ‘‘prepper’’ basement in Offenbach, Germany.

item.title: Vaccinations begin at the nursing home where 46 died in the pandemic’s first days.
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy
item.media:credit: Karen Ducey/Getty Images
item.media:description: The Life Care Center of Kirkland, a nursing home near Seattle, was the site of the first U.S. coronavirus outbreak. Residents and staff members received vaccinations on Monday.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: China clamps down on travel amid new cases.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Mass testing in Dalian, China, last week. The virus is once again set to interrupt Lunar New Year celebrations.

item.title: Spain will register those who choose not to get vaccinated, and will share the information with the E.U.
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder
item.media:credit: Emilio Morenatti/Associated Press
item.media:description: Vaccination should be considered “an act of solidarity toward our loved ones and our citizenship,” said Spain’s health minister, Salvador Illa.

item.title: Small Number of Covid Patients Develop Severe Psychotic Symptoms
item.description: Most had no history of mental illness and became psychotic weeks after contracting the virus. Cases are expected to remain rare but are being reported worldwide.
item.dc:creator: Pam Belluck
item.media:credit: Jovelle Tamayo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Hisam Goueli treated several psychotic patients who had never had mental health issues before, including a woman who told him she kept visualizing her children being murdered. “It was like she was experiencing a movie,” he said.

item.title: The Most-Read Stories of 2020
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: A celebration in Atlanta after Joe Biden won the presidential election.

item.title: Revisiting the Unseen Corners of the World
item.description: During a year with limited travel possibilities, our World Through a Lens series offered Times readers a weekly escape. Here are some of the highlights.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Chloë Ellingson

item.title: Italy uses flowers to help spread a vaccine message.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Doctors, nurses and health care assistants began receiving the coronavirus vaccine at a hospital in Piacenza, Italy, on Sunday.

item.title: Vaccine, Brexit, Trump: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brigitte Werner, 70, was vaccinated in Munich on Sunday.

item.title: The big question for the U.S. vaccine campaign: Who’s next?
item.description: Not all states will follow the guidance of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:credit: Brian Kaiser for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fritz Jackson, an emergency medical worker in Ohio, received a dose during the first phase of U.S. vaccinations.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Vaccines roll out across Europe.
item.dc:creator: Carole Landry
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brigitte Werner, 70, was vaccinated in Munich on Sunday.

item.title: Reginald Foster, Vatican Latinist Who Tweeted in the Language, Dies at 81
item.description: One of the world’s foremost experts on Latin, Father Foster was a monk who looked like a stevedore, dressed like a janitor and swore like a sailor.
item.dc:creator: Margalit Fox

item.title: 1 of every 17 people in the U.S. has been infected, and 1 in 1,000 has died. Yet the worst may lie ahead.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Wolfe and Andrea Kannapell
item.media:credit: Alex Welsh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nurses at Arrowhead Regional Medical Center administered coronavirus tests at the hospital’s drive-through testing site in Colton, Calif., this month.

item.title: In efforts to vaccinate Europeans, a push to overcome skepticism.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy and Marc Santora
item.media:credit: David W Cerny/Reuters
item.media:description: Emilie Repikova, a World War II veteran, left, and Prime Minister Andrej Babis of the Czech Republic received vaccine jabs in Prague on Sunday.

item.title: Jobless benefits run out as Trump resists signing the relief bill.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.media:credit: Erin Scott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Two unemployment measures expired on Saturday after President Trump refused to sign the bill.

item.title: New Year's Eve Playlist From Around the World
item.description: This year finally coming to an end is reason enough to celebrate a bit. Even if you had to stay home, your music can travel the world.
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Modak
item.media:credit: Helene Pambrun/Paris Match, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Aya Nakamura performing in 2019.

item.title: Central and Southern California Have 0 Percent I.C.U. Capacity
item.dc:creator: Bryan Pietsch
item.media:credit: Ariana Drehsler for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gabriella Ortega, a respiratory therapist, speaks to a health care worker who is helping to treat a Covid-19 patient at Providence St. Mary Medical Center in Apple Valley, Calif., on Dec. 17.

item.title: A Beloved World War II Photo Comes to Life in a Virtual Reunion
item.description: Martin Adler, now 96, was looking for German troops in 1944 when he almost shot three Italian children. His daughter’s internet appeal brought them all together again this month.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Matteo Incerti, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Martin Adler in 1944 with the Naldi children, Bruno, Mafalda and Giuliana, in the northern Italian village of Monterenzio.

item.title: Neverland Ranch Is Sold for $22 Million
item.description: Ronald W. Burkle, the billionaire co-founder of the investment firm Yucaipa Companies, bought the ranch for a reported $22 million.
item.dc:creator: Marie Fazio
item.media:credit: Armando Aroriyo/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Under Michael Jackson’s ownership, the Neverland Ranch in Los Olivos, Calif., was transformed into an entertainment complex, complete with amusement park rides, a zoo and a train.

item.title: Germany and Hungary Begin Vaccinations a Day Early
item.description: The full rollout of the European Union’s vast vaccine campaign begins Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Fabio Bucciarelli for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman received received vaccine at Amedeo di Savoia hospital in Turin, Italy, on Sunday.

item.title: U.K. Virus Variant Found in Japan, Spain and France
item.description: The discovery of the U.K. variant has prompted more travel restrictions.
item.dc:creator: Ben Dooley, Raphael Minder, Marc Santora, Isabella Kwai and Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Kyodo News via Getty Images
item.media:description: The discovery of the virus variant in Japan prompted the country to close its borders to all new entry by nonresident foreigners.

item.title: Austria enters its third lockdown. Israel is set to follow suit.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy and Adam Rasgon
item.media:credit: Ronald Zak/Associated Press
item.media:description: Until Jan. 24, people in Austria are only allowed to leave their homes for work, shopping or to exercise outdoors, and personal contacts are limited to no more than two households.

item.title: Pompeii's Savory New Finds: Snail, Fish and Sheep Soup, Anyone?
item.description: The ancient site is the archaeological gift that keeps on giving. A food shop excavated this month suggests that its ancient residents had singular culinary tastes.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo

item.title: The truck jam at a U.K. port is easing, days after France reopened its border.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Peter Nicholls/Reuters
item.media:description: Ferries at the Port of Dover in England on Saturday morning. About 1,600 vehicles remained in the traffic jam while at least 8,000 had crossed the English Channel via the Eurotunnel since Wednesday.

item.title: It’s lonely on the top, and in the lodge, as ski resorts struggle.
item.dc:creator: Kellen Browning
item.media:credit: Cayce Clifford for The New York Times
item.media:description: A lift at Squaw Valley, which has had only a trickle of skiers.

item.title: Truck Jam Eases at U.K. Port Days After France Reopens Border
item.description: Even with new restrictions around the world to try to stop the transmission of a virus variant sweeping rapidly across Britain, the mutation has already spread to France, Spain and Japan.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Peter Nicholls/Reuters
item.media:description: Ferries at the Port of Dover in England on Saturday morning.

item.title: George Blake, British Spy Who Betrayed the West, Dies at 98
item.description: He was caught spilling secrets to the Soviets in 1961 and imprisoned. Five years later, he escaped and fled to Moscow, where he was hailed as a hero.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden
item.media:credit: Central Press/Hulton Archive, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The British agent George Blake arriving in England in 1953 after he was released from captivity in North Korea. He was held for three years but denied that the indoctrination he received had influenced his conversion to Communism.

item.title: Sailors Stranded for Months as China Refuses to Let Ships Unload Australian Coal
item.description: China is vague about why vessels that carried Australian coal to its ports can’t unload their cargo. “We’re all depressed; our mental health is deteriorating,” one sailor said.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Geng Yuhe/VCG, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Cranes unloading coal from a cargo ship at Lianyungang port in China in August. Crews on some ships carrying Australian coal have been stranded in Chinese ports for months.

item.title: 1895: Wretched Weather Mars Christmas in London
item.description: Rain, snow and driving sleet hit the British capital 125 years ago, though a program offering poor children a hamper of holiday foods was a bright spot.
item.dc:creator: The International Herald Tribune

item.title: France and Japan report cases of the virus variant that prompted lockdowns in Britain.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: A theater in Le Havre, France, that was transformed into a coronavirus screening center. The country reported its first case of the new virus variant on Friday.

item.title: She Chronicled China’s Crisis. Now She Is Accused of Spreading Lies.
item.description: Zhang Zhan, who reported about the coronavirus from Wuhan during the lockdown, will face trial next week, in the first known case against a citizen journalist from the crisis.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Reuters
item.media:description: People in an alley near the Yellow Crane Tower in Wuhan, in late February. Zhang Zhan was part of a wave of journalists, professionals and amateurs, who went to Wuhan at the beginning of the pandemic.

item.title: Brexit Deal Done, Britain Now Scrambles to See How It Will Work
item.description: Britain is finally departing from the European Union, but its formal exit is only the beginning of a high-stakes experiment to unstitch commercial relations across an integrated continent.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller
item.media:credit: Kirsty Wigglesworth/Associated Press
item.media:description: Trucks at the port at Dover on Friday. Truckers got an alarming preview of the havoc caused by shipping delays when they were stranded because of bans connected to the coronavirus variant.

item.title: Images of Light: Christmas Services Penetrate Darkness Around the World
item.description: Despite the pandemic, Christmas traditions endure, shedding some brightness in a gloomy season.
item.dc:creator: Herbert Buchsbaum
item.media:credit: Yasuyoshi Chiba/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Receiving Communion during a Christmas service in Nairobi, Kenya.

item.title: With Pandemic Raging, London Homeless Take Shelter in Hotels for a While
item.description: Many homeless people in London will stay in hotels over the Christmas and New Year holidays, if not longer, through funding from charities and the government.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteers for Crisis at Christmas deliver breakfast to homeless people in their rooms in a London hotel that is housing so-called rough sleepers over the Christmas period.

item.title: ‘Box’ or Gem? A Scramble to Save Asia’s Modernist Buildings
item.description: Groups across the region are rallying to save buildings that officials consider too new, too ugly or too unimportant to protect from demolition.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hong Kong’s General Post Office, built in 1976, was designed by K.M. Tseng, a government architect in what was then a British colony.

item.title: Russian Police Arrest a Top Navalny Ally, Lyubov Sobol
item.description: The police detained Lyubov Sobol amid a crackdown on activists seeking to draw attention to the nerve-agent poisoning of the opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Pavel Golovkin/Associated Press
item.media:description: The opposition activist Lyubov E. Sobol, second left, with Aleksei A. Navalny, center, in Moscow in February.

item.title: Pope Francis Makes Christmas Appeal for Nations to Share Covid-19 Vaccines
item.description: The pope made his remarks from inside the Vatican instead of before large crowds on St. Peter’s Square, as Christians around the world scaled back or reimagined Christmas traditions.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo and Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Vatican Media, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Humanity must not “allow the virus of radical individualism to get the better of us,” Pope Francis said on Friday in his annual Christmas address.

item.title: Brexit Deal Poses Threat to Boris Johnson and U.K. Conservative Party
item.description: Conservatives are united for now over the British prime minister’s trade deal, but as details emerge, he could face challenges from hard-liners and business groups.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Celebrating in London in January as the United Kingdom officially left the European Union.

item.title: UK Increasingly Isolated as US Restricts Travel Due to Coronavirus
item.description: America’s requirement that passengers coming from Britain provide negative coronavirus tests is just the latest woe to strike the country this Christmas period.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A deserted shopping district in London. The rapid spread of a coronavirus variant prompted the lockdown of the city and southern England.

item.title: 25 Stories for December 25th
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Esther Horvath
item.media:description: Climate scientists outside their icebreaker, which has been frozen in Arctic ice since October.

item.title: How Covid-19 Vaccine Launch Evokes Memories of Polio Era
item.description: Many older Americans, shut in during this year’s pandemic, share haunting recollections from the polio era of their childhood.
item.dc:creator: Emma Goldberg
item.media:credit: via Lynn Seymour
item.media:description: Lynne Seymour, center, in Berkeley with her mother in 1954.

item.title: Stateless, She Became the Face of a Largely Invisible Plight
item.description: Maha Mamo had no citizenship. Born in Lebanon of Syrian parents, she was ineligible for either nationality. It took her years of perseverance and some lucky breaks to find a homeland — in Brazil.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño
item.media:credit: Erin Kirkland for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maha Mamo, born stateless in Lebanon, received Brazilian citizenship after years of advocacy to end statelessness, a legal limbo endured by millions globally.

item.title: Adapting to a Holiday Season Stripped of Its Essence
item.description: Pandemic restrictions mean friends and families will not be gathering this year, but Canadians are coming together in other ways.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Ian Austen/The New York Times
item.media:description: Officials have urged Canadians to stay at home during the holidays this year.

item.title: In One Person, the Story of a Place
item.description: Since 2002, the Saturday Profile has sought the universal in characters around the world.
item.dc:creator: Julia Carmel
item.media:credit: Ksenia Kuleshova for The New York Times
item.media:description: Simon Gronowski played piano out his window while his neighbors stayed home during a wave of the coronavirus in April.

item.title: US Will Require UK Travelers to Have a Negative Coronavirus Test
item.description: The new rule, which takes effect on Monday, will apply to Americans as well as foreign nationals.
item.dc:creator: Russell Goldman and Isabella Kwai
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Eduardo Munoz/Reuters
item.media:description: A passenger from Britain at Kennedy Airport in New York this week. A new, highly transmissible variant of Covid-19 has led dozens of countries to impose restrictions on travel from Britain.
